title: Permutation Groups - Symmetric Group and Cycles

questions.prompt: The symmetric group Sₙ consists of:
options: All cyclic permutations of n elements
questions.explanation: The symmetric group Sₙ is the group of all permutations (bijections) of a set with n elements, under composition.

questions.prompt: What is the order of the symmetric group S₅?
questions.explanation: The order of Sₙ is n!. For S₅, this is 5! = 5·4·3·2·1 = 120.

questions.prompt: The cycle (1 3 5 2) in S₅ sends 1 to:
questions.explanation: In cycle notation, (1 3 5 2) means 1→3, 3→5, 5→2, 2→1. So 1 is sent to 3.

questions.prompt: What is the order of the permutation (1 2 3)(4 5) in S₅?
questions.explanation: The order of a product of disjoint cycles is the lcm of their lengths. Here lcm(3,2) = 6.
Two cycles are disjoint if they move no common elements. An important property is that disjoint cycles commute with each other.

title: Permutation Groups - Even/Odd and Alternating Group

options: It can be written as a product of an even number of transpositions
It moves an even number of elements
It is in Sₙ where n is even
questions.explanation: A permutation is even if it can be expressed as a product of an even number of transpositions (2-cycles).

questions.prompt: What is the parity of the permutation (1 2 3 4 5)?
questions.explanation: An n-cycle has parity (-1)^(n-1). The 5-cycle (1 2 3 4 5) has parity (-1)^4 = 1, so it's even. Alternatively, (1 2 3 4 5) = (1 2)(2 3)(3 4)(4 5), which is 4 transpositions, hence even.

questions.prompt: The alternating group Aₙ consists of:
questions.explanation: The alternating group Aₙ is the subgroup of Sₙ consisting of all even permutations.

questions.prompt: What is the order of the alternating group A₄?
questions.explanation: The alternating group Aₙ has order n!/2. For A₄, this is 4!/2 = 24/2 = 12.

questions.prompt: The product of two even permutations is:
questions.explanation: The product of two even permutations is even. This is why the set of even permutations forms a subgroup (Aₙ).

title: Permutation Groups - Dihedral Groups and Cayley's Theorem

options: Symmetries (rotations and reflections) of a regular n-gon
questions.explanation: The dihedral group Dₙ consists of all symmetries of a regular n-gon, including n rotations and n reflections.

questions.prompt: What is the order of the dihedral group D₄ (symmetries of a square)?
questions.explanation: D₄ has order 2n = 2(4) = 8. It consists of 4 rotations (including the identity) and 4 reflections.

questions.prompt: In the dihedral group Dₙ, if r is a rotation by 360°/n and f is a reflection, which relation holds?
questions.explanation: In Dₙ, the key relation is rf = fr⁻¹ (or equivalently frf = r⁻¹). This captures the non-commutativity of rotations and reflections.

options: Every group is isomorphic to a subgroup of some symmetric group
Every finite group is isomorphic to Sₙ for some n
questions.explanation: Cayley's Theorem: Every group G is isomorphic to a subgroup of the symmetric group on G, denoted S_G. This shows permutation groups are fundamental.

questions.prompt: According to Cayley's Theorem, a group of order 6 can be embedded in:
questions.explanation: Cayley's Theorem guarantees that a group of order n embeds in Sₙ. So a group of order 6 embeds in S₆. (It might also embed in smaller Sₘ, but S₆ is guaranteed.)
